newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada PM angers Westerners with election call.
newsitem.headline: Canada PM angers Westerners with election call.

text.p: Canadian Prime Minister Jean Chretien's re-election campaign has sprung a leak in Western Canada amid voter anger with his decision to hold a federal election during Manitoba's worst flooding in 145 years.

Despite a commanding lead in nationwide opinion polls, support for Chretien's Liberal Party appears to be suffering in the West -- from flood-ravaged Manitoba on the prairies to British Columbia on the Pacific coast.
Chretien's election call 1-1/2 years earlier than required despite the floods has revived chronic complaints that the West's concerns are ignored in Ottawa.
Westerners have long felt that the eastern provinces of Ontario and Quebec unfairly dominate national politics. Quebec is Chretien's native province.

"The Manitoba flood is another bead on the rosary of grievances in the West," said Allen Seager, director of the Centre for Canadian Studies at Simon Fraser University in Vancouver. "The anger is an illustration of the electoral marginalization felt by people in the West."

The Liberals are nonetheless expected to win enough seats in Parliament to form another majority government. A Reuters survey by the Zogby International polling firm released on Monday showed the Liberals supported by 47.6 percent of decided voters, more than 30 points ahead of their nearest rivals.

But in Manitoba, Saskatchewan and Alberta, the Liberals trailed the right-wing Reform Party and were ahead of Reform by only a slim margin in British Columbia. The West is the traditional stronghold for Reform, based in Alberta.
In the prairie provinces of Manitoba and Saskatchewan, the Zogby poll showed Reform leading the Liberals by 35.5 percent to 25.4 percent, with the left-wing New Democratic Party at 20.6 percent.
The Zogby poll found that 68 percent of western voters did not think there was a good reason to call an election now and that number rose to 79 percent in the prairies.

Chretien visited flood-ravaged Manitoba a day before calling the vote on April 27. Many westerners were irritated by images of Chretien touring the dikes with a media entourage while residents scrambled to save their homes.

Handed a sandbag when visiting one hard-hit area, the prime minister asked what he was supposed to do with it, a comment that for some Manitoba residents has come to symbolise his detachment from their plight.
Chretien has tried to blunt the criticism by sending $25 million Canadian (US$18.5 million) in emergency aid to Manitoba last week and has promised more help to come.

But some political analysts believed the bitterness would recede with the floodwaters and not have a major impact on the final vote tally. "It seems like it's a relatively short-lived effect," said pollster John Zogby.
